title: 115_s3074
content: The "Focus on Children Act" is the short title of this legislation. It requires the Congressional Budget Office to conduct studies and reports on how legislation impacts spending on children. Section 202(g) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for spending on children studies and reports. Definitions for terms such as 'budget of the President' and 'child' are provided within this amendment. Key indicators related to specific outlays are also included in the amendment. The amendment to Section 202(g) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 includes provisions for spending on children, defining terms like 'budget of the President' and 'child'. It outlines specific outlays that qualify as spending on children, including outlays under entitlement authority and for programs delivering services exclusively to children. The amendment to Section 202(g) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 includes provisions for spending on children, specifying outlays for programs benefiting children and conducting studies upon request. The Director is required to submit an annual report to Congress within 15 days after the end of each fiscal year, containing information on spending on children under appropriation Acts and entitlement authority. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress within 15 days after the President's budget submission, detailing spending on children under appropriation Acts and entitlement authority for the prior, current, upcoming, and ensuing fiscal years. The Director must submit an annual report to Congress within 15 days after the President's budget submission, detailing spending on children under appropriation Acts and entitlement authority for the prior, current, upcoming, and ensuing fiscal years. The report includes a summary of the total amount of appropriations or new obligational authority and outlays requested for spending on children, an estimate of the level of spending on children, the share of Federal spending on children, and the date when Federal spending on children will be less than outlays for interest on the public debt. Additionally, the Director may provide warning reports to Congress regarding a fiscal year at their discretion. The Director may issue warning reports to Congress about a fiscal year where interest on the public debt surpasses spending on children. The reports may include budgetary options for Congress to address this imbalance. Additionally, the Director is required to publish all reports and studies in a publicly accessible format for transparency. The Director is mandated to develop a public dashboard tool to highlight key indicators and visualize trends in spending on children. The Director is required to create an open data portal providing raw quantitative data on spending on children in a widely-accessible format categorized by budget account.
